Hello All.

I present the Firewing of Corellon Larethian to you. To her elven patron she owes her song and love of the arts. To her draconic heritage she owes her might. I hope you like her.

She started off in the Build Request forum in the thread, "Whistle While You Work", which gives her background and my thinking in her construction, and she's now fit for members' consumption. I have made a few amendments/fixes. The amendments include taking an option I suggested as a possible tweak, in that she now focuses on longsword early and the greatsword for a more deadly presence later (though sword and board can still be used if required). My sums had also mucked up the skill points I had available, which I've now fixed. I also did find another build with the same classes and distribution in the Legacy Archive: Cati the Holy Edge by Sam Elanius in 2008. However, that build is human, takes Dev Crit much later and takes only 4 Great Strengths, finishing on Strength 38. I believe Firewing surpasses that, while retaining her elven grace.

With no further ado...

posts.content: Your health will improve later.  Later RDD levels will give more health, as will CoT levels, and when you get RDD 7, the CON boost will give you a lot of health at once.

posts.author: Stagmeister
posts.content:
Okay. Bard gives hps of d6 + Con modifier (currently 1) per level. CoT gives d10 + Con mod. RDD is somewhat different, in that it gives d6 + Con mod for the first 3 levels, d8 + Con mod at levels 4 and 5, and d10 + Con mod from levels 6 -10 (d12 + Con mod from 11 onwards, but that doesn't concern us here). The reason I don't specify the constitution modifier here is because when you hit RDD 7 you get a +2 boost to Con, so from level 19 onwards that modifier becomes 2 rather than 1.

So, simply put, you get 7 hps p/level from levels 1-8 (so 56 is spot on), 9 hps at levels 9 and 10, 11 from level 11-16, another 7 at level 17, 11 at 18, and 12 from 19 onwards, except at 27 and 37 when it's 8.

Hope this helps rather than confuses!

Cheers

EDIT: Ninja'd by Empyre, but I'll let it stand. Actually, I can't remember atm (sorry, just woken up) if the Con boost at RDD 7 is back-dated like Toughness is?

EDIT 2: Have just checked on the wiki, and the boost to Con is indeed retroactive, so you'll also get a further 18 hps when you hit RDD7 at level 19 (thus 30 hps  in total at that level).

posts.author: Maximillian_Kane
posts.content:
Hey Stag!

Since you pointed me in this direction, I thought I'd leave you my 2 cents:

First of all, kudos. This is a VERY strong build, and what I like the most about it is the slickness of going Elf to circumvent the need to take Weapon Focus on a crappy weapon. That said, it's all about where you play. This build doesn't really need to wield a 2-hander, and IMO it loses more than it gains, because the 1.5x damage will only be an issue when you don't crit, which is NOT going to be often. And in those cases, it may be better just to have a higher AC. 

So, in order to have options to fight with a higher or lower AC as desired / necessary, as well as improve the level 40 power of the build, I'd do the following:

1- Drop Heavy Armor Proficiency. You'll get it through CoT anyway.

2- Drop WF: Greatsword. Transfer all your feats to your Longsword and carry a 2-hander (preferably a Heavy Flail, since Undead reduce slashing and piercing damage and Bludgeoning resistance is harder to come by) without focus in case you'd like to make the switch. I'm not saying you shouldn't use 2-handers, I'm saying you don't need the feat investment.

3- With the 2 feats, take Luck of Heroes to further improve your 3 saves, or Great Fortitude in case you're going to face DevCritting monsters or PCs. They will surely go down first in a battle of DevCritters. Then take Expertise with the second feat to make your AC more malleable. (regardless, unless you go for LoH, Expertise is probably best at level 1 to help compensate for the lack of Heavy Armor those first few levels).

4- Drop Spot and/or Spellcraft for Taunt to make use of the Taunt / Expertise combo. That makes both your AC and AB malleable. You need AC, fight in Expertise for +5 AC. Need AB, fight in Expertise, then Taunt, then drop Expertise and gain up to +6 AB. Need AB and AC, Fight in Expertise, Taunt, re-activate Expertise and you'll have +1 AB and +5 AC.

5- I'd delay Devcrit a bit for a few extra skill points by taking RDD 9 ASAP. Since skill points aren't retroactive, the sooner you take them the better.

6- I'd go Bard 6 / CoT 6 / RDD 8 pre-epic so I could get RDD 9 as early as level 21, to maximize those skill points. That would only delay Devcrit by 2 levels. You'd have it by level 25. If you're planning to play this build all the way to 40th level, then it's no big loss. In MTS, you'll have it before the end of Act 1.

Again, IMO this is a VERY GOOD build, so I don't see any shortcomings that are not able to be overcome by smart in-game decision-making. This means I wouldn't weaken the end result just to make it easier to play for a couple of levels. But, as you know, that's my style of building. Each to their own.

Cheers!

Many thanks Max, it's greatly appreciated!

And you're right about environment playing a crucial role, I just hope Firewing is adaptable enough to accommodate appropriate tweaks such as you suggest without being a completely different build.

She did start life as a "pure" longsword-wielder, which leaves room for Expertise (I think LoH would be something of a luxury in a build with all saves already over 30), but I'd been paying attention in class a few years back when certain of the great and good expressed the view that anything with a strength of 30+ deserves the extra wallop of a 2-hander. I don't know, you veterans are a slippery bunch .

And that applies equally to delaying Dev Crit. Who was it first advised that I should take Dev Crit asap assuming it's in the build? Honestly! (If you need a hint, they have the initials MK.)

I do get what you say about Taunt, and I confess it would have appealed to me if I wasn't so rubbish (yes, still) at your Taunt/Expertise combo. However, I've always been a bit of a saves junkie when it comes to fighting mages - particularly Will - as there's nothing worse for a meleer than not being able to do its one job (hit stuff). I also like to have at least one detection skill for those damned sneakers. So, it was personal preference, really, but again is tweakable.

Alas, I can tell you've been away for a while, my friend - CoT doesn't get heavy armour prof, as you very well know!

As ever, a very valuable 2 cents worth! Thanks again for your thoughts.

Cheers

I think you can (if I'm understanding you right), but it involves taking Bard 6 earlier rather than level 5 later ('cos you can't do that), so there's a knock-on effect to when you take Tumble. If you take Bard 6 at level 13 you get your 15 UMD, and you delay the CoT bonus feats by 1 level each pre-epic. You also have a 14 level gap until your next Tumble dump (+3AC rather than +2), so it's up to you.

Hope this is the sort of thing you were looking for!

If I might raise a small note of caution: much as I love me some dwarf (and I do), you'll have to spend 5 points on CHA at character creation just to get it to 11, which is the minimum you need for Bard. All other races (except half-orc) only require 3, so you might be gimping others among your starting stats. Human obviously has its benefits - more skill points and an extra feat are always nice. I went with elf primarily to grab a better weapon earlier on, because of the race proficiency in longswords and longbows, but I suppose you could use that extra feat for Martial Weapon Proficiency.

Regardless, really pleased you're giving her a go!
